stance_1: I do not seek out meat
stance_2: I eat meat when it is available
justification: The interviewee states they do not seek out meat but do eat it when available; these are complementary habits.

stance_1: I do not seek out meat
stance_2: I sometimes prefer other foods over meat
justification: Not seeking out meat aligns with sometimes preferring other foods over meat.

stance_1: I eat meat when it is available
justification: Eating meat when available is implicitly supported by the belief that meat is nutritious.

stance_1: I eat meat when it is available
justification: Eating meat when available is implicitly supported by the belief that meat gives energy.

stance_1: I eat meat when it is available
stance_2: I sometimes prefer other foods over meat
justification: Preferring other foods over meat sometimes conflicts with eating meat when it is available.

stance_2: I eat meat when it is available
justification: The interviewee's family eats meat, supporting the habit of eating meat when available.

stance_1: My friends prefer non-fatty meats for health
stance_2: I eat meat when it is available
justification: Friends preferring non-fatty meats for health may contrast with eating whatever meat is available, but the evidence is weak.

stance_1: My friend avoids beef for religious reasons
stance_2: My friends prefer non-fatty meats for health
justification: One friend avoids beef for religious reasons and another prefers non-fatty meats for health, indicating different motivations for restricting meat choices.
